title: Persimmon hails 'confident' housing market as it records healthy profit rise
text:
Persimmon hails 'confident' housing market as it records healthy profit rise The housebuilder's profits rose by 23% to £774.8m last year. Share A Persimmon development (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Housebuilding giant Persimmon has notched up a healthy rise in full-year profit as it pointed to a “confident” housing market, despite concerns over Brexit. 
The business, which was founded by Northumberland’s Duncan Davidson , said pre-tax profits rose 23% to £774.8m in the year to December 31, while revenue rose 8% to £3.1bn. 
Persimmon said: “Despite some understandable caution being exercised by consumers and corporates alike during the period ahead of the EU referendum, the result created an immediate and significant uncertainty in the markets. 
“However, the vast majority of the group’s customers remained focused on exchanging contracts and completing their new home purchases.” 
Chairman Nicholas Wrigley added customer activity in the early weeks of the 2017 spring season has been “encouraging”. 
The company said of current trading: “The UK new build housing market remains confident with customer demand for new homes supported by compelling mortgage products. We are pleased with customer activity in the first eight weeks of the 2017 spring season. Read More IT industry alarm as less than 1% of students do computing A-level 
“Visitors to our sites are circa 7% ahead year on year. We have experienced a normal week-on-week strengthening of the market on entering the 2017 spring selling season.” 
Buyer demand and house prices have been surprisingly resilient since the referendum, the company said, thanks largely to rock-bottom borrowing costs after the Bank of England halved interest rates to 0.25% in August. 
Persimmon also flagged the “overall shortage of supply of housing in the UK” as a factor providing support to the market. Read More Newcastle firm Orange Bus signs contract with Sahara Force India Formula 1 team 
However, the company added: “We remain wary of the risks and increased uncertainties associated with the EU referendum result. 
“The group is in a strong position to remain selective in its land replacement activities given the strength of its existing asset platform.” 
Legal new home completions increased by 599 to 15,171 and the average selling price rose 3.8% to £206,765 last year. 
Fellow housebuilder MJ Gleeson also showed itself to be in a strong position at the half year mark after increasing the number of homes its sild by 12.8%. The firm’s interim results showed it had sold 451 homes in the first six months of 2016/17, 51 more than the same period the year before. The firm’s profit before tax increased by 1.8%, from £11.3m to £11.5m. 
Dermot Gleeson, chairman of MJ Gleeson, commented: “Gleeson Homes is on track with its ambitious growth plans. It continues to experience strong demand both in its established operating areas and in the new areas into which it is expanding. Reservations are at record levels.” Like us on Facebook
